OP

how do you guys cope with the fact that OF egirls are making tens of millions a year? this shit is really unbelievable man i am seething so hard holy fuck

61889273
I literally just don't care. Nobody will ever love them and I can also make 10 million without displaying my butthole for the world to see

61889278
It's only like top1% creators making millions

61889279
>>61889273
i didnt care too for so long but now im starting to care fml its just so unfair.. Not only are they extremely hot they also get to make 20MM a year for years scamming with bikini pics on OF

its just so unfair i feel like crying

Latest replies (last 30, oldest → newest)

61889429
>>61889409
It's an enormous amount of work too when you get big enough to make decent cash but not enough to sustain yourself. Answering 48 messages in the morning yourself because you can't afford to pay a guy to do it for and you can't not answer because these guys are shelling out 70 percent of your revenue. Then you return. Film more. Do it again and scrape by for maybe 900 bucks a month.

It's almost more worth it to end up being worth a few cheeseburgers so you know you aren't worth it.

Most importantly where are some places you can use Link as collateral to borrow Xrp to take full advantage of the trade of the century?

>>61889606

Buy XRP

XRP and LINK are complete LARPs that nobody even trusts

61890891
>>61890390
>common enterprise
You bought a product, not a share. Everything you just wrote proves this is a speculation and not an investment.

61891011
>>61889827
>https://ripple.com/insights/institutional-defi-on-xrpl-scaling-real-world-finance-with-xrp-at-the-core/
You keep posting same article like its some kind of mic drop moment. As if linking it over and over suddenly turns it into undeniable proof. It doesn’t lol Youre taking a CEOs words at face value because you think hes personally invested in making you rich. Thats not how this works. CEOs promote their companies and his job is to literally sell you XRP.

61891035
>>61889600
Thanks spammy.

>>61889620
/thread

61891717
>>61891011
I'm not. It is literally the products they are building and the material they are releasing detailing it to shareholders. Link sell directly to retail every time there is a minor pump. You are literally saying nothing but standing in a way where you think if you come across as affirmative in a direct way it will seem like you are. Lol You are just doing what you accuse me of (which I am not) saying we can't trust it to be true because it is relying on the words of someone. It literally isn't. They are structuring XRPL core amendment pushes and having their staff code them based on the product suite fit detailed in the article. They made multiple multibillion dollar acquisitions, including a fucking prime broker to actuate it all. And most importantly, the majority of their treasury is in XRP and their products are ALL made more efficient and cost efficient using it and they are incentivized to increase the price of XRP they have in escrow and cannot sell, unlike CLL who dump what was supposed to be operator rewards on retail always and are LITERALLY a fraud designed to milk your savings (exactly what you project Ripple to be, which it isn't because the XRPL actually solves efficiencies instead of sticking a tollbooth in the middle of process for literally no reason like a jewish parasite). The entire XRPL is designed to automatically use XRP for auto-bridging between assets etc. Your argument sucks and it is hilarious that it actually applies to link, which you are capable of seeing but literally don't care because you are in a literal cult pretending to object but just obsessively committed to a project that is the least morally redeemable or utility having one in all of crypto for literally no reason than ego and entrenched specific coin cultism. Really odd and gay.

61891755
>>61890083
Extreme cope. SWIFT said it would take 15 years MINIMUM to even get a product active. I am not sorry to let you know that by that time SWIFT will have 100% missed the boat and payments will have been completely revolutionized, not needing them. You hitched your dingy to a big ship, but it turned out it was the Titanic, which we all always said. Way too little way too late presuming the ethgate lawfare would win but it didn't.
>>61890250
>MPT/permissioned dex is the standard
No it hasn't. You literally don't know what either of those things are. No other ledger at scale has a built in dex and amm and protocol layer compliance like permissioned dex nor the broadness of the MPT standard. It definitely has been The Standard, but not in the way you think. MPT is not "wrapped assets." Here is an AI slop video that is actually informative which possibly someone at your level of research will be able to be spoonfed by:
https://youtu.be/3kYXW_o-N4Y

>>61890891

61891914
>>61890307
>>61890390

61892108
>>61891887

Also may I just congratulate you on your point that ripple is incentivised to increase the price of Xrp since that is most of their treasury, unlike CLL who also has most of their treasury in Link but is not incentivised to increase the price. I thought that was most salient.

>>61889600

61892185
>>61891717

when the token will be needed for functioning of the network

61892592
>>61891914

61892659
>>61892185
I already mentioned it you fucking retard. You can see the ledger amendment history that they have spent their own dev money and time developing, their acquisitions of Hidden Road, etc. their getting binance listing RLUSD on the XRPL, the fact the early team specifically coded the ledger to explicitly default to its use and to save several percentage points over Ripplenet alone by doing so, the fact that they locked the vast bulk of their corporate treasury up in timed release in it, the fact they fund and partner with multiple large banks to drive and encourage its use and adoption, and the fact the services they are building out literally optimize using it and offer counterparty-less feature that no other asset onchain can, and the fact that they already use it in their business. They literally legally can't use it in most contexts yet but with clarity their business can become much more efficient and as a result their core holding increases in value. There is LITERALLY no reason to argue they are not building for its use other than being butthurt that it is true and trying to repress reality like a faggot. They literally have Fednow service providers running XRPL nodes and big banks who are their largest outside investors issuing bonds that reward in XRP (who were celebrated recently in their specific crypto efforts by the financial regulator of Japan) and are partnering with DBS (biggest bank in Singapore (Switzerland of Asia) and Franklin Templeton (trillion plus dollars AUM) building out a repo market on the XRPL. They got ONDO issuing on the XRPL, one of the largest asset managers in Europe/England doing same while basically no one is getting headway in England, Societe General (one of biggest banks in Europe) expanding to include XRP for their euro stablecoin which can bridge to RLUSD using XRP, etc. Literally everything they do builds around corporately driving XRP's adoption, literally just fleshing out a business sweet around it.

61892679
>>61892659
>>61892185
This isn't even 10% of what could be said partnership etc. wise. XRP and link are different in that XRP actually improves business performance and has a reason to exist and incentivizes use in products. Link is literally just a toll booth jew token to insert costs where they would not technologically exist.

>>61892108
The difference is CLL dumps on retail all the time and their business is not improved by the operation of link, it is a technologically pointless token, literally. Ripple hasn't sold publicly in over 5 years to retail.

insider here, again.

Open thread • Replies: 32 • Updated: 2026-02-24 00:22 UTC

Early replies (first 3)

61879648

61879767
>>61879648
getting dumped on by OP

61879836
>>61879767
Due to my current occupation, I am prohibited from holding stocks, options, or similar investments.

Latest replies (last 30, oldest → newest)

61879895
This you?

61879921
>>61879767
idk I mean bed bath was once a huge American retail darling...the historic overstock chart is super schizo/presently quite low...these warrants are trading like a shitcoin which is funny...I also don't dislike lemonis. He's a media player and if you actually listened to some of his shit there does seem to be an interesting intersection between blockchain capabilities and homeownership etc...not financial advice of course just a variety of things I was peeking at when researching

61879944
>>61879263
no

61879999
>>61879836
What is your current occupation anon? Nothing revealing but in general etc...the exercise price of the warrants is $15...trading currently at less than a dollar it seems like a confusing deal...at this point if one likes the company wouldn't shares be the move? I did some modeling around warrant prices if the shares price goes to xyz and that is very interesting...also speaking of interesting what's the deal with the alleged cusip similarity to the old bbbyq shares?

61880091
>>61879999
Financial system. I am not asking you to hold those warrants until they are exercised. I am asking you to hold them and sell the warrants when we can realize a substantial profit. Nice quads.

61881477
>>61880091
Interesting. Wouldn't trading the warrants implicitly come with a short term capital gains tax insofar as its impossible to hold them over a year at this point? Would have to be some pretty fair gains to offset that 40% hit...anyways doesn't the warrants increasing in price also imply that the shares have gone up in price as well? I ran some informal modeling estimates using black scholes with iv, roughly .65 years to expiry and this is what I came up with: 15.5 bbby share price = 4.50ish warrant price...25 share price/12ish warrant price...60 share price/45ish warrant price...100 share price/85ish warrant price...200 share price 185ish warrant price...I make no claim as to the veracity of these numbers, just for fun. Anyways what do you see happening to the bbby stock price for these warrants to be worthwhile? Am I thinking on the right track in general?

61881670
>>61879263

61881753
>>61879999
>>61881477
note the digis

61881916
>>61879263

Latest replies (last 30, oldest → newest)

61892250
>>61889694
he meant anal gay intercourse, and it's the only true statement he ever made in his entire life

61893402
>>61889731
It isn't coming. LLMs are useful for some things but the notion that they are going to anything other than a glorified search engine needs to die. Yeah they are good a being a search engine, search engines are useful, but they suffer from the same problems as search engines, namely that a internet search can never actually tell you if the information it find is accurate.

Research needs to look an entirely different direction if they want true intelligence. We've been working on text generators for decades so it shouldn't be surprising that we've managed to perfect them, but the next breakthrough is going to come from something else we've been working on for decades, not from incremental improvements to LLMs.

Who knows, maybe LLMs can aid in the research of this alternative field which will bring the next advancement? Using better technology to do research can cut down the years required so the accelerated nature of technology remains, but it is still going to come from somewhere people aren't expecting.

LLMs can still be useful, but the costs associated with it are going to become prohibitive. Eventually they are going to just be like railways or telecoms which serve as an expensive base over which the next thing can emerge.

61893571

item.title: privacy: Ring signatures with 16 decoys make the true sender indistinguishable. — 3 replies — 12.0/hr
item.content:encoded:
privacy: Ring signatures with 16 decoys make the true sender indistinguishable.

Open thread • Replies: 3 • Updated: 2026-02-24 00:43 UTC

OP

privacy:

Ring signatures with 16 decoys make the true sender indistinguishable.

One-time stealth addresses prevent linking transactions to recipients.

Pedersen commitments hide values. Bulletproofs prove validity without revealing amounts.

Dandelion++ obscures transaction origin on the network layer.

Each output carries a mandatory fixed-size encrypted memo envelope (128 bytes). Wallet/API expose memo as text or hex payload.

FCMP coming in weeks not years.

Would you mine this anon?

>>61893271

item.title: Ai is about to crash the economy — 21 replies — 19.7/hr
item.content:encoded:
Ai is about to crash the economy

Open thread • Replies: 21 • Updated: 2026-02-23 23:50 UTC

OP

This was released today by citrini

AI gets good. Companies lay off workers. Margins expand. Stocks rip. S&P hits 8,000. Everyone celebrates.

• But fired workers stop spending. Companies weaken. They buy more AI to cut costs. More layoffs. Less spending. A negative feedback loop with no natural brake.

• The top 10% of earners drive 50%+ of all consumer spending. They're the ones getting replaced. A $180K product manager ends up driving Uber for $45K. Multiply that across every major city.

• Ghost GDP emerges - the economy is "growing" on paper, but the money never reaches real people. Productivity is booming. Wages are collapsing.

• Then it hits housing. $13 trillion in mortgages, all underwritten on one assumption: you keep your job for 30 years. In 2008, the loans were bad on day one. In 2028, the loans were good. The world just changed after they were written.

• S&P crashes 38% from highs. Unemployment hits 10.2%. Markets barely react anymore.

• The punchline: you're not reading this in 2028. You're reading it in February 2026. Every domino they describe has already started falling.
